content: Fireflies use bioluminescence to communicate with each other and attract mates by emitting flashes of light. The specific pattern of flashing varies by species, and males and females may have different patterns to help them recognize each other. The male firefly flies around flashing its light in a specific pattern attracting the attention of females. If the female likes what she sees, she responds with her own flashing pattern, indicating that she is ready to mate. This process of flashing back and forth continues until the male and female meet and mate. Fireflies also use bioluminescence to ward off predators by emitting a bright flash of light to startle their predators and make them drop a potential prey.
